results.title: The Day the Sun Rose Twice: A Tour of Atomic New Mexico
results.abstract: The Southwestern state was central to the development of nuclear weapons. When the testing ground for the first detonation recently reopened for visitors, a writer decided to confront that difficult history.

media.caption: The undulating dunes of White Sands National Park, in Alamogordo, N.M., are surrounded by the White Sands Missile Range, where the first atomic bomb was test detonated in 1945.

results.title: These Cakes Have Thorns
results.abstract: A group of bakers are taking nonconformist cake decorating trends to new heights, creating otherworldly confections bristling with surreal protrusions.

media.caption: From left: Gigi’s Little Kitchen’s vegan confetti cake with lemon buttercream, sugar pearls, wafer butterflies, dried flaxseed pods and preserved scabiosa pods; and vegan confetti cake with vanilla buttercream, dried cherries, sugar pearls, wafer butterflies, dried baby’s breath and preserved scabiosa pods, from $275 each, gigislittlekitchen.com. Aimee France’s chai cake with brown butter salted cardamom maple crème fraîche buttercream, grapes, calendula and gem marigolds; chocolate cake with mixed summer fruit jam, amaranth, Eastern hemlock pine cones, flowering peppermint and a Comice pear; olive oil cake with brown butter lavender buttercream, zinnias, lemon thyme, sweet alyssum flowers and a Concorde pear, from $300 each, aimeefrance.com.
media.copyright: Photograph by Chase Middleton. Set design by Maria Santana

results.adx_keywords: Economic Conditions and Trends;Rural Areas;AGRICULTURE AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS;United States;United States
results.byline: By Roy Reed Special to The New York Times
results.title: Back‐to‐Land Movement Seeks Self‐Sufficiency
results.abstract: NY Times survey finds self-sufficiency has become battle-cry of full-scale back-to-the-land movement that has attracted thousands of Amers since antiwar movement of '60s; finds established politics and economics are beginning to feel impact of movement, especially in New England, and that scattering of extension service agents and other Govt agr officers have begun to take it seriously in several states; cites broad aim of movement as seeking ways to live simply but well on the land outside econ insts that dominate US; finds movement is deeply antagonistic to Amer econ system, whose adherents it sees as controlled by unbridled corp power, corrupted with surfeit and crazed by impulse to consume and waste; finds most back-to-the-land advocates are young and believe movement will have impact on Amer system comparable to Civil Rights movement; notes recent Census Bur svy which shows rural areas have been gaining population faster than urban areas since '70; migration to New England, W Coast, Vt, Rocky Mts, Southern highlands, Upper Middle West, Pa, NY, Ore and Ozarks noted; illus (L)

results.adx_keywords: Religion and Belief;Mosques;Christians and Christianity;Muslims and Islam;Jews and Judaism;Culture (Arts);Architecture;Middle Ages (Historical Period);Columbus, Christopher;Spain;Seville (Spain)
results.byline: By Aatish Taseer and Richard Mosse
results.title: In Search of a Lost Spain
results.abstract: In the southern part of the country, churches and streets hold the remnants of eight centuries of Islamic rule.

media.caption: The ceiling of the Hall of Ambassadors in the Alcazar in Seville, Spain. Built by Peter I of Castile (1334-69), the structure is an example of the Mudéjar style of architecture, in which Islamic ornamentation and building techniques were overlaid with Christian meaning.
